subject: Release test document
commitMessage:
Release test document

Resolves openbmc/openbmc-test-automation#1769

Change-Id: I13d04bcedba0b1fa0073ef5bcc5cfee2588a7942
Signed-off-by: Sivas SRR <sivas.srr@in.ibm.com>

Patch Set 1:

Based on discussion during our test community call, had come up with openbmc functional test specification. Associate with https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc-test-automation/issues/1769.

Do not use colon characters in section headings
Done

Wrap lines to 80 characters (similar to https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
Use longer lines for links (line 3 above) as needed.
Spelling
Done
Done

Define your acronyms:
Functional Test Cycle (FTC):
Done
I understand this means: The direction is to move away from the phosphor-REST APIs, but they are still in use and are part of this test plan.
So as of now, leaving that statement there itself. Hope it is fine, Joseph.
Yes, please remove trailing space.  In Emacs you can: M-x delete-trailing-whitespace
Done - I didnt see trailing space with Vi editor though.
move to previous line?
Done
remove leading space
Done
Change all tabs to spaces
Done
Spelling: Yocto
Done
Intel (capitalize)
Done

Change to: OpenPOWER
Can you add a reference to the OpenPOWER project?  Perhaps link to https://openpowerfoundation.org/
It seems like you need some way to help your readers understand when you use OpenPOWER terminology (such as PNOR) later in this document.
Done
Redfish (first letter capitalized)
Done
What is an "official build"?  Does this mean the fix is verified using the normal development process?
"official build" means what is available in openpower.xyz or what release notes indicates.

This bullet feels like an IBM specific statement.
This main idea is that we can leave minor defects in the code.
How is that different from the previous bullet?
Yes, make sense, removed it.
What does "officially released" mean?  Does this mean the code has to be merged into the master branch or into a stable release branch (such as warrior for 2.7.0)?
code has to be merged and it is available in http://openpower.xyz/ or location indicated by release notes.
remove blank line?
Done

You could probably shorten this paragraph up a little.

The objective of OpenBMC FVT is to verify that the hardware and firmware perform according to architectural specifications.  This is done through both black box and white box testing.
Done
verification *tests
Done

"problems that would ensure usability" doesn't read right.  Maybe this?

"...and fix problems with the OpenBMC-based servers."

- "functionality tests are focused on...functionality" - reads as a little redundant.

Maybe drop "functionality" from the start of the sentence:

- Do you need "(OpenBmc)" in there?

- "focus" vs "are focused" - when reasonable, use active voice.

These tests focus on the basic hardware and firmware functionality to ensure...
Done. Retained (OpenBMC), Mike. Because we test OpenBMC only.
Capitalize the first word in each of these bullet points.
Done

"requisite" and "requirements" basically mean the same thing:

##  Functional Verification Test (FVT) Pre-requisites
Done
- Test target machine must be <whatever you need to say here>
I'm not clear on what this means.
Basically functionality should be available in OpenBMC with unit test completion from development side.

OK.  Something more like this then?

 - Initial unit-test has been performed by product code developers.
Because this is the actual name of a tool, make it all lower case.
Done
U may want to remove this

George, We can leave it, In case if community also interested, We can still allow, right. 
And this is useful tool for them as well. What do you say?

Well I dont think we should add something specific support to certain org. Though its open , its not designed to address the community to align to keep this documentation very generic.

Same with HTX tool as well.

Since you're listing the phases, can you make this a bullet point?

- Functional Test Cycle (FTC):
Done

Redundancy:

"meets architectural specification" and "meets architectural specification" pretty much say the same thing twice.

Here's my attempt at it:

Ensure that function implementation meets architectural specifications as
documented in  the design document.  In this phase, function owners work
closely with test owners.

Note that I chose to use the "phrase-as-an-English-command" approach.  Certainly not obligatory though.
Done

Since you're listing the phases, can you make this a bullet point?

- FVT Regression Phase:

In the first bullet you DON'T include the word "phase" and here you do.  Pick a way and do it the same for both.  My preference is to remove the word "Phase" since we already know by the section of the document that these are phases.
Done

Am I right in saying that regression testing is done regularly on changed product code and not just once as a phase.  It may be good to phrase this to include that information:

Regularly re-run selected test cases on changed firmware to ensure that no existing functions have been broken.  The selection of tests is chosen by the test team leaders to deliver the greatest value for the necessarily limited amount of test run time.
Need a response here.
We need to define what is FTC in terms of community.. This looks like of the definition. we will need to get buy in from community who ll be responsible for xyz orgs or community as a whole

"e.g." essentially means "For example" so a little redundancy here.  Since this document is more formal, go ahead and spell it out:

For example, run HTX on...
Done
Any newly introduced OpenBmc feature falls within the scope of FVT.  This includes any features from the various supported interfaces such as Redfish, REST, IPMI, GUI, etc.
Done
I'd just drop the "Not sure" sentence.
Done

I'm not sure what you're saying here.

Do you mean that the features that you're talking about in the first paragraph are limited to features that can be accessed directly by the end-user?  What about features that are only accessed indirectly?  Don't those count?
Removed, Done.
If a function is purely firmware or host related, then it would not fall within the OpenBMC FVT test scope.
Is it correct ot have "firmware" included in the prior sentence?  Isn't it our mission to test OpenBMC firmware?  Or did you mean other firmware?
host firmware is system firmware. Our scope is to test OpenBMC firmware.

No need to use the word "list" when a list clearly follows:

Features currently in OpenBMC FVT scope:

- Collapse double space to single.
- Put the various types of code update in parenthesis:

 - Code update (both OpenBMC and PNOR)
Done

- Watch the caps
- Shorten like this:

 - Host power on/off
Done
*including
Done
- Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP)
- Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) certificates

Is "OS continous boot" one of many "HTX Soft bootme" functions?  Maybe this would clarify:

 - HTX Soft bootme: OS continuous boot
Done
- HTX Hard bootme: Whole system power cycle and boot all the way to OS and run HTX
Done

- Collapse double spaces
- Do we even need the "depends on" phrase?  If so, I'd parenthesize it.

 - GPU/IO related test (depending on availability of adequate HW)
Features which are related to testing using OpenBMC commands like busctl, systemctl, etc. are considered as out of scope.
Done

"Methodology" doesn't seem to be the right term here.

# Test Types
Done
What is a host test?  Does it fit into this list?
Related to system / host

- For your section headers you seem to follow the rule of capitalizing each word in the title so be sure to do that here as well.
- Is this the entry criteria for FTC phase?  If so, can that also be included in the title?

**Entry Criteria For FTC:**
Done

I think I was initially confused because I thought you were talking here about machine state requirements for a given test (like setup and teardown stuff).  Am I now correct that you're simply saying that some OpenBMC functions may enter the test phase as soon as they meet the requirements even though not all other functions are ready?
yes.

- The function *behavior should...

- You're writing each of these bullet points as full sentences so make sure you end all of them with a period.
*case ("case" is being used as an adjective so it should not be plural).

Run-on sentence.  Change ";" to "." and capitalize "the".

 - The target driver is identified. The...

Also, is "driver" a good industry standard term here?  I don't know the answer.
Done

Drop "new".

 - All code for...
Done

- Why _FTC_ vs FTC?

Address throughout if you change it.
Done

- "setup" should be "set up" in this context.  "setup" is a noun.  "set up" essentially a past-participle.
- End "etc" with a period.  Fix globally.
Done
*set up
Done

End sentence and start a new one:

ready).  In addition...
Done

You don't need to say both "All" and "100%".  "100%" sounds more emphatic so I'd go with that one:

...include: 100% of test cases...

Fix throughout.
Done

- This is a sub-bullet to the one on line 145.  Can you indent it accordingly along with any other relevant bullets?

- Capitalize the first word ("The").

Could this all be said more simply?

  - The test case execution either succeeds or there is a defect record open to document the failure.

...with a firmware image build by the build server (currently openpower.xyz).
Done
This are witherspoon specific.. so we shouldnt have here
Done
This is also OEM specific, shouldnt be listed here
Done
This are upcoming work and not for Master 2.7

We would need to expand and say what FVT stands for by forware declaring it. since we are using it all over in the documentation.
Done
Are we talking here about what the OpenBMC test community is doing or should do vs  just a generic test documentation ?
this is openbmc test community.
Can u add the link where are those specification architecture
That is hardware architectural specification, George. It can be Witherspoon for IBM, Romulus for Google etc.

we dont fix, but just identify / raise bug / report to community.
so drop that
Done
we do more than basic testing.. so u can use "generic" instead
Done

drop this.. we support what OpenBMC community support, shouldnt be just those two based

" OpenBMC based servers"

This shouldnt be the case, the test focus could be for Witherspoon but in a spec support unless u named the "openbmc_functional_test_specification.md" to "openbmc_ibm_functional_test_specification.md" we shouldnt add this one
Done

Well to be generic, we would need to reword this. something in the line to say.

 - Test target machine should be OpenBMC supported systems.

Joseph/Kurt can comment here.
Done

Well, since the openbmc design doc talk about software design flow  but it neither detailed to the point to actual says its a design document per se but accepted in openBMC to say we document it.

so architectural or specification wouldn't be the correct term here.. you can just say

"derived application requirement"
Make sense, Done.
Collapse double space to single (my fault :).
Done
Is this an expectation or a directive statement ?. This is more of a generic functional case than what openbmc community should do collectively. would need reword
There are functional owners who sign off Kurt Taylors's excel sheet and similarly test owner also sign off. I am meaning that, George.
new or re-designed

please drop this word.
Done

Indent this bullet and any others which are sub-bullets of bullet at line 145.

They are sub-bullets mike.
     - A redesign and/or code implementation correct the misbehavior. The
       defect is then verified with an official build and closed.
     - With the OpenBMC community approval, document the new behavior for
       the end user (customer) as the expected behavior.
     - Defect verification and test case re-execution may not use sandbox
       build or firmware patch. All defect fixes have been integrated, built,
       and verified with a firmware image build by the build server
(https://openpower.xyz).

Do you need a date/owner?
If you keep, these look better with a new line between them
